verses.text: Rejoice in the LORD, you righteous! Praise is fitting for the upright.
verses.comment: The psalm opens with a call to worship from the just. Here, the Catholic tradition often sees the 'righteous' as those justified by grace through the sacraments, hinting at a communal worship that is deeply connected to participation in the liturgy.

verses.text: Give thanks to the LORD with the lyre; make music to Him on a ten-stringed harp.
verses.comment: Musical worship is not only an external expression; in Catholic liturgy, the use of instruments and song draws the worshiper to deeper participation in the mystery of Christ.

verses.text: Sing to Him a new song; play skillfully with joyful shouts.
verses.comment: The 'new song' is often seen as a symbol of renewed life in Christ (cf. Revelation 5:9). The renewal theme resonates with Catholic theology on the transformation through the sacraments.

verses.text: For the word of the LORD is right, and all His works are done in faithfulness.
verses.comment: God’s word here foreshadows the Word made flesh (John 1:1). The Catholic tradition links the reliability of God's word to both Scripture and Tradition as channels of revelation.

verses.text: He loves righteousness and justice; the earth is full of the LORD’s unfailing love.
verses.comment: The overflowing love ('hesed') reflects the Catholic understanding of divine grace permeating creation, not just a select group.

verses.text: By the word of the LORD the heavens were made, and by the breath of His mouth all their host.
verses.comment: The creative word ('dabar') anticipates Christ, the Divine Word (John 1:1-3). Catholics see this as support for the doctrine that all creation is sustained in Christ.

verses.text: He gathers the waters of the sea as a heap; He puts the deeps in storehouses.
verses.comment: God’s mastery over the cosmic waters is a sign of His lordship and power, echoing Catholic liturgical prayers that remember creation and the symbolism of water in baptism.

verses.text: Let all the earth fear the LORD; let all the inhabitants of the world stand in awe of Him.
verses.comment: All nations are called to reverence God. In Catholic thought, this hints at the universality of the Church’s mission and salvation (cf. Matthew 28:19).

verses.text: For He spoke, and it came to be; He commanded, and it stood firm.
verses.comment: God’s power to create by His word prefigures the spoken words of Christ and the efficacious nature of sacramental words in Catholic tradition.

verses.text: The LORD brings the counsel of the nations to nothing; He frustrates the plans of the peoples.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over world affairs is a reminder of His providence. In Catholic thought, history unfolds under God’s guidance, often contrary to human designs.

verses.text: The counsel of the LORD stands forever, the plans of His heart to all generations.
verses.comment: The permanence of God’s will echoes the Catholic teaching on the enduring faithfulness of God’s covenant—a covenant sealed and fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Blessed is the nation whose God is the LORD, the people He has chosen as His inheritance.
verses.comment: Israel as God’s chosen nation is a type of the Church, the new people of God, as taught in Catholic doctrine (cf. 1 Peter 2:9).

verses.text: The LORD looks down from heaven; He sees all the children of mankind.
verses.comment: God’s universal gaze points toward the dignity of every human as taught in the doctrine of creation.

verses.text: From where He dwells, He looks out on all the inhabitants of the earth.
verses.comment: The psalm emphasizes God’s transcendence but also His immanence, a theme developed in Catholic spirituality.

verses.text: He forms the hearts of all; He observes all their deeds.
verses.comment: God’s shaping of the human heart corresponds to Catholic teaching on prevenient grace and the transformative work of sanctification.

verses.text: No king is saved by the size of his army; no warrior escapes by his great strength.
verses.comment: Human resources are inadequate for salvation; true reliance must be on God—anticipating the Catholic view of salvation not by works alone, but by grace.

verses.text: The horse is a false hope for salvation; by its great might it cannot rescue.
verses.comment: Earthly powers cannot save; Catholics see in this the necessity of supernatural means, such as the sacraments and prayer.

verses.text: Behold, the eye of the LORD is on those who fear Him, on those who hope in His lovingkindness,
verses.comment: 'Fear' and 'hope' go together; Catholic doctrine upholds both reverent awe (filial fear) and trust in God's mercy as essential virtues.

verses.text: that He may deliver their soul from death, and keep them alive in famine.
verses.comment: Deliverance from death here is physical but points toward spiritual salvation in Christ, fulfilled most fully through the resurrection—at the center of Catholic faith.

verses.text: Our soul waits for the LORD; He is our help and our shield.
verses.comment: 'Waits' denotes hopeful trust—a quality the Catholic Church sees as cultivated especially in the community gathered in prayer and sacraments.

verses.text: For our heart rejoices in Him, because we trust in His holy Name.
verses.comment: 'Holy Name' hints at a deeper revelation in Christ (cf. Philippians 2:9–11), and the Catholic devotion to the Holy Name reflects this same confidence.

verses.text: Let Your lovingkindness, O LORD, be upon us, even as we hope in You.
verses.comment: The final prayer unites hope and God's steadfast love—a classic emphasis in Catholic spirituality, cultivated in the Eucharist, which is the source and summit of Christian hope.
